TEXT ORDER setting briefing schedule and hearing. Defendants shall respond to Plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction on or before December 12, 2023. Plaintiffs shall file their reply, if any, on or before December 19, 2023. The Court will hold a hearing on Plaintiffs' motion on December 22, 2023, at 9:00 a.m. in Courtroom 265. On or before December 13, 2023, each side must file a Notice stating whether it intends to present testimony at the hearing and, if so, the length of time it reasonably expects the testimony to last. The parties are advised that the Court may consolidate the hearing with a similar hearing in Case No. 4:23-cv-478. If necessary, the Court will have time available in the afternoon of December 21 if the parties believe a single day will be insufficient for the hearing. The parties should so advise in the Notices filed on or before December 13, 2023. Signed by Judge Stephen H. Locher on 12/6/2023. (mm) (Entered: 12/06/2023)

TEXT ORDER regarding hearing on motions for preliminary injunction. All parties in Case No. 4:23-cv-00474 and Case No. 4:23-cv-00478 have now responded and confirmed that they do not intend to offer live testimony at the hearing on the motions for preliminary injunction. The Court is therefore satisfied that the single consolidated hearing on December 22, 2023, at 9:00 a.m., will be sufficient to address the motions in both cases. Accordingly, the Court DENIES the Penguin House Plaintiffs' request for a separate hearing. The Court anticipates the following order of events at the December 22 hearing: (1) the GLBT Youth Plaintiffs will present argument on their motion; (2) the Penguin House Plaintiffs will present argument on their motion; (3) the State of Iowa Defendants will present argument in response to both the GLBT Youth and Penguin House motions; (4) any other Defendants wishing to be heard will present argument; (5) the GLBT Youth Plaintiffs will present rebuttal argument, if any; and (6) the Penguin House Plaintiffs will present rebuttal argument, if any. There are no other hearings scheduled before the undersigned on December 22, and thus all parties will be given as much time as they reasonably believe they need to argue their positions. The Court is likely to have substantial questions for all sides regarding, among other things, the constitutional rights at issue, the scope and governing standards for those rights, and the proper interpretation of the relevant provisions of the challenged legislation. Signed by Judge Stephen H. Locher on 12/14/2023. (mm) (Entered: 12/14/2023)

TEXT ORDER denying without prejudice 90 Plaintiffs' Motion for Leave to Amend Complaint. Contrary to Plaintiffs' suggestion, Local Rule 7(d) does not excuse a party from filing a brief in support of a motion to amend pleadings under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 15, especially when as here the motion is not consented to by all other parties. Plaintiffs may refile the motion with an attached supporting brief as required under Local Rule 7(b)(3). Signed by Chief Magistrate Judge Stephen B. Jackson, Jr. on 5/24/2024. (jeb) (Entered: 05/24/2024)

TEXT ORDER Denying Without Prejudice 51 Motion to Dismiss for Failure to State a Claim, 91 Motion for Preliminary Injunction, and denying 97 Motion for Extension of Time to File. On May 28, 2024, the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit entered an order staying further proceedings in this Court pending appeal of the temporary injunction ruling. In light of the stay, the Court DENIES WITHOUT PREJUDICE 51 Motion and 91 Motion and DENIES AS MOOT 97 Motion. To the extent consistent with the mandate from the Eighth Circuit, the parties may renew their respective motions following remand, including making any changes they believe are appropriate to conform to the Eighth Circuits ruling. case_data.name: GLBT Youth in Iowa Schools Task Force v. Reynolds
case_data.plaintiff_description: A non-profit dedicated to supporting LGBTQ+ youth and eight students in Iowa

related_cases.name: Penguin Random House, LLC v. Robbins

case_data.summary:
The Iowa governor signed SF 496 into law on May 26, 2023. SF 496 includes an Age-Appropriate Standard, an Identity and Orientation Prohibition, a Library Restriction provision (together, the Book Restriction provisions), and a Parental Notice provision. The Age-Appropriate Standard dictates that school libraries must contain “only age-appropriate materials” which cannot include “any material with descriptions or visual depictions of a sex act.” SF 496 defines sex act broadly and does not account for the value of a book as a whole or its literary, scientific, medical, artistic, or political value. The Age-Appropriate Act also draws no distinction between what is appropriate for a kindergartener versus a high school student.  The Identity and Orientation Prohibition also prohibits school libraries from providing any program or promotion relating to “gender identity” or “sexual orientation” to students in kindergarten through sixth grade. SF 496 does not define what constitutes a program or promotion, nor does it provide guidance was to what types of materials “relate” to gender identity or sexual orientation. Under SF 496, teachers, libraries, and other educators face license sanctions and adverse employment actions for violations of SF 496, including termination of their employment. The Library Restriction provision facilitates anonymous complaints by parents requesting the removal of material from classrooms and libraries. Finally, the Parental Notice provision mandates that school officials notify a student’s parent or guardian when the student asked to use a name or pronouns that differ from those in the school’s records, even if the official is aware that a student will be rendered unsafe or vulnerable to abuse as a result. SF 496 was set to go into effect on January 1, 2024.

On November 28, 2023, an LGBTQ+ non-profit and eight students attending Iowa schools brought this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Iowa. Represented by the ACLU of Iowa, Lambda Legal, and private counsel, plaintiffs brought this lawsuit against the Governor of Iowa, the Iowa Department of Education (IDOE), the director of IDOE, the Iowa State Board of Education (ISBE), the Iowa City Community School District, the Sioux City Community School District, the Urbandale Community School District, the Waterloo Community School District, and the West Des Moines Community School District, as well as each of the school district superintendents and individual members of their school boards. Plaintiffs alleged that the Age-Appropriate Standard and Identity and Orientation Prohibition provisions of SF 496 violated Plaintiffs’ First and Fourteenth Amendment rights in several ways:

  • The Book Restriction provisions constituted content- and viewpoint-based restrictions on the right to receive information in violation of Student Plaintiffs’ First and Fourteenth Amendment rights.
  • The Book Restriction and Parental Notice provisions violated all Plaintiffs’ rights under the First and Fourteenth Amendment by chilling and depriving their freedom of speech and expression.
  • The Book Restriction and Parental Notice provisions violated all Plaintiffs’ rights under the First and Fourteenth Amendment by depriving their freedom of expressive association.
  • The Book Restriction and Parental Notice provisions violated all Plaintiffs’ rights under the First and Fourteenth Amendment because it was unconstitutionally vague.
  • The Book Restriction provisions violated all Plaintiffs’ rights under the First and Fourteenth Amendment because it was unconstitutionally overbroad.
  • The Book Restriction and Parental Notice provisions violated the rights of all Plaintiffs to Equal Protection under the Fourteenth Amendment by discriminating on the basis of sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, and transgender status.
  • The Book Restriction and Parental Notice provisions violated all Plaintiffs’ rights under the Equal Access Act, 20 U.S.C. § 4071, by denying equal access or a fair opportunity to Gay Straight Alliances in schools.

Plaintiffs asked that the court grant declaratory relief, attorneys’ fees and costs, and permanent injunctive relief enjoining defendants from enforcing the relevant provisions of SF 496. The case was assigned to Judge Stephen H. Lochner and Magistrate Judge Stephen B. Jackson.

Contemporaneously with their complaint, on November 28, 2023, Plaintiffs filed a motion for preliminary injunction, asking the court to enjoin defendants form enforcing SF 496 while the litigation proceeded. On December 19, 2023, school district defendants filed their opposition to Plaintiffs’ motion for preliminary injunction, and the state defendants filed their opposition on December 20.

The school district defendants also filed a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim on December 20, arguing that (1) the school district defendants were not the moving force behind Plaintiffs’ injuries, (2) the school district defendants could not be held liable for following state law, and (3) alternatively, the claims against the individual school district officials should be dismissed as duplicative of the claims against the school districts.

The court held oral argument regarding Plaintiffs’ motion for preliminary injunction on December 22, 2023. This oral argument was held simultaneously with the oral argument for a motion for preliminary injunction in Penguin Random House, LLC v. Robbins, 4:23-cv-00478, which also challenged the constitutionality of SF 496.

On December 29, 2023, the district court granted in part Plaintiffs’ motion for preliminary injunction. The court enjoined defendants from enforcing the Book Restriction provisions, but denied Plaintiffs’ motion for preliminary injunction as it pertained to the Parental Notice provision. The court first analyzed which plaintiffs had standing to challenge which provisions of SF 496. The court found that students had standing to challenge the Book Restriction provision because it directly restricted what books they could access in their school’s library. However, seven of eight Student Plaintiffs did not have standing to challenge the Book Restriction provisions insofar as Student Plaintiffs argued that such provisions restricted their freedom of speech or association, as the court found that any such restriction was a result of Plaintiffs’ perception of the law rather than the law itself. Only one Student Plaintiff had standing to bring such a first amendment challenge because she was the only plaintiff under grade six, and SF 496 therefore posed stricter restrictions on her compared to her co-plaintiffs. Additionally, the court found that no Student Plaintiff had standing to challenge the Parental Notice provision because all of the named Student Plaintiffs were already out to their families and as such suffered no concrete injury. Turning to the merits of parties’ arguments, the court found that the Age-Appropriate Standard was overbroad and unlikely to survive any standard of scrutiny and that the Identity and Orientation Prohibition, while facially neutral, was likely void for vagueness under the Fourteenth Amendment. For these reasons, the court enjoined defendants from enforcing the Book Restriction provisions while the case proceeded. 2023 WL 9052113.

The state defendants appealed the court’s order on preliminary injunction on January 12, 2024 to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit (24-1075).

On January 17, 2024, defendants filed a motion to stay proceedings in the district court pending the appeal in the Eighth Circuit. On the same day, the district court temporarily granted the motion, asking Plaintiffs and school district defendants to respond to their motion explaining how they would be harmed by a stay pending appeal. Following motion practice, the district court partially lifted the stay, setting a deadline for Plaintiffs to respond to school district defendants’ motion to dismiss. Plaintiffs filed their opposition on February 27, 2024, and school district defendants filed their reply on March 8, 2024.

In the district court, Plaintiffs filed a motion to allow limited discovery and motion practice on May 21, 2024. Specifically, Plaintiffs asked to proceed with limited discovery against the school board defendants only. Plaintiffs also asked to move to amend their complaint only as it pertained to claims not on appeal in the Eighth Circuit. Finally, Plaintiffs asked for leave to move to renew their motion for preliminary injunction as to the Parental Notice provision, as they sought to amend their complaint with facts demonstrating injury and standing. The district court granted the motion on May 23, 2024, allowing Plaintiffs to proceed with limited discovery and move to amend their complaint a renew their motion for preliminary injunction. The Plaintiffs filed their motions the same day. Also on the same day, state defendants moved for the court to reconsider its order granting Plaintiffs’ motion, arguing allowing Plaintiffs to amend their complaint now as opposed to after the Eighth Circuit ruled on their appeal would prejudice them significantly. On May 24, the district court denied defendant’s motion to reconsider and Plaintiffs’ motion to amend but gave both parties leave to refile.

On the same day, in the Eighth Circuit, the state defendants moved to stay proceedings in the district court pending their appeal. The Eighth Circuit granted defendants’ motion on May 28, 2024 without giving their reasoning. In response to the circuit court’s order, the district court denied school district defendant’s motion to dismiss and Plaintiffs’ renewed motion for preliminary injunction on May 29, 2024, and stayed all proceedings in the district court.

The Eighth Circuit set oral argument for June 11, 2024. 

On August 9, 2024, the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed a district court’s preliminary injunction that had blocked enforcement of Iowa’s Senate File 496, holding that the lower court didn’t apply a broad enough interpretation as the Plaintiffs brought a facial challenge to SF 496. Thus, the appellate court vacated the injunction and remanded the case for further proceedings, while noting plaintiffs were still free to seek injunctive relief under the framework set out in Moody v. NetChoice, LLC, 144 S. Ct. 2383, 2397 (2024). 


The District Court issued an order requesting the Plaintiffs submit amended pleadings on September 25, 2024, after the Eighth Circuit vacated the preliminary order injunction in this case and the related case: Penguin Random House, LLC v. Robbins. 


Back in the District Court, Plaintiffs filed a renewed Motion for Preliminary Injunction on their claims that SF 496 was overbroad, vague, and infringed upon their First Amendment rights pursuant to the requirements for a facial challenge set out in the Eighth Circuit’s opinion on October 19, 2024. In support of this motion, Plaintiffs filed a brief arguing that SF 496 violated the First and Second Amendments through its three principal provisions: the “Library Restriction,” “Gender Identity/Sexual Orientation Prohibition,” and the “Gender Identity Notification Provision.” 


On October 23, 2024, the Plaintiffs filed their first amended complaint, which included an updated factual background discussing events pertaining to the original preliminary injunction and a renewed request for injunctive relief. 


On February 6, 2025, the District Court heard arguments regarding Plaintiff’s motion for preliminary injunction, and on May 15, 2025, the Court granted and denied the motion in part. The court held that restrictions on “curriculum, tests, surveys, questionnaires, or instruction” about gender identity or sexual orientation for kindergarten through sixth-grade students could survive if narrowly interpreted to bar only mandatory instruction giving detailed explanations or normative views, but not neutral references. However, it found the bans on “programs” and “promotions” facially unconstitutional under the First Amendment, thereby protecting student groups like GSAs and permitting schools to advertise and support them. The court also struck down the parental notification law as unconstitutionally vague except for cases where a student requests different pronouns. The court reaffirmed its earlier injunction blocking book bans on works containing sexual acts. 


In response to the Court granting in part the Plaintiff’s motion for preliminary injunction, Defendants gave notice of appeal on June 13, 2025. Shortly thereafter, on June 15, 2025, Defendants filed a motion to stay proceedings, which was granted on the same day.
case_data.summary_short: This case centers around SF 496, and Iowa law that dictates that school classrooms and libraries (1) must contain โonly age-appropriate materialsโ which cannot include โany material with descriptions or visual depictions of a sex act,โ and (2) could not provide any program or promotion relating to โgender identityโ or โsexual orientationโ to students in kindergarten through sixth grade. SF 496 also mandates that school officials have to notify parents if their child uses a name or pronouns not listed in school records. On November 28, 2023, an LGBTQ+ non-profit and eight students brought this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Iowa. Represented by the ACLU of Iowa, Lambda Legal, and private counsel, plaintiffs brought this lawsuit against the Governor of Iowa, the Iowa Department of Education (IDOE), the director of IDOE, the Iowa State Board of Education (ISBE), the Iowa City Community School District, the Sioux City Community School District, the Urbandale Community School District, the Waterloo Community School District, and the West Des Moines Community School District, as well as each of the school district superintendents and individual members of their school boards. Plaintiffs alleged that SF 496 violated their rights under the First and Fourteenth Amendments, as well as the Equal Access Act, 20 U.S.C. ยง 4071. Plaintiffs moved for preliminary injunction, and the district court granted preliminary injunction on December 29, 2024. Defendants appealed the courtโs order on preliminary injunction to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Oral argument was set for June 11, 2024. On August 9th, the Court of Appeals reversed the injunction, holding that the district court's legal reasoning was flawed and remanded proceedings. In response, on October 19th, 2024, Plaintiffs filed a renewed Motion for Preliminary Injunction, followed by their first amended complaint four days later on October 23rd, 2024. After hearing arguments, the Court granted in part and denied in part the motion for preliminary injunction on May 14, 2025. In their order the court held that restrictions on โcurriculum, tests, surveys, questionnaires, or instructionโ about gender identity or sexual orientation for kindergarten through sixth-grade students could survive if narrowly interpreted to bar only mandatory instruction giving detailed explanations or normative views, but not neutral references. However, it found the bans on โprogramsโ and โpromotionsโ facially unconstitutional under the First Amendment. Defendants appealed the District Courtโs order and filed a motion to stay proceedings, which was granted.

  Plaintiffs IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS f/k/a GLBT YOUTH IN IOWA SCHOOLS TASK 
FORCE  (โIOWA  SAFE  SCHOOLSโ);  P.B.-P.,  by  his  parent  and  next  friend  BELINDA 
SCARROTT; A.C., by their parents and next friends RICHARD and ULRIKE CARLSON; T.S., 
by her parent and next friend ERIC SAYLOR; B.F.S., by their parents and next friends BRIGIT 
and JOSEPH STEVENS; B.F., by their parent and next friend LARA NEWSOM; JAMES DOE,

and through their undersigned counsel, respectfully bring this challenge to recently enacted Senate 
File 496, 2023 Iowa Acts ch. 91 (โSF 496โ or โthe lawโ), an unconstitutional law that violates 
Plaintiffsโ First Amendment, Fourteenth Amendment, and Equal Access Act rights. Plaintiffs 
submit to the Court this First Amended and Supplemental Complaint requesting a declaratory 
judgment and preliminary and permanent injunctive relief against all Defendants, their employees, 
agents, and successors in office. Contemporaneously with this First Amended and Supplemental 
Complaint,  Plaintiffs  submit  a  Renewed  Motion  for  Preliminary  Injunction  with  Brief  and 
Declarations in support. In support of their First Amended and Supplemental Complaint and 
Renewed Motion for Preliminary Injunction, Plaintiffs state the following: 
2 
 

Case 4:23-cv-00474-SHL-SBJ   Document 121   Filed 10/23/24   Page 3 of 177
 
PRELIMINARY STATEMENT 
1.  Plaintiffs are a non-profit advocacy organization serving lesbian, gay, bisexual, 
transgender, queer, or questioning (โLGBTQ+โ) Iowa youth, which brings suit on behalf of the 
organization itself and on behalf of the organizationโs members comprising both individual 
students and gender sexuality alliance chapters1 (โGSAsโ), six LGBTQ+ students from Iowa who 
attend Iowa public schools and whose ages range from ten to seventeen, and two educators. They 
challenge as unconstitutional and unlawful under federal statute SF 496, a sweeping piece of 
legislation signed into law by Governor Kim Reynolds on May 26, 2023, which primarily amends 
portions of Title VII (Education and Cultural Affairs) of the Iowa Code.  
JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
2.   This Court has subject matter jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. ยงยง 1331 and 1343 
because this action arises under the First and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States 
Constitution and 42 U.S.C. ยงยง 1983 and 1988 and seeks to secure equitable relief under an Act of 
Congress, 20 U.S.C. ยง 4071.  
3.   This Court has personal jurisdiction over Defendants because Defendants are 
domiciled in the State of Iowa and the deprivation of Plaintiffsโ rights arises out of and relates to 
Defendantsโ official duties in the State of Iowa.  
4.  Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง 1391(b)(1) and (2). 
PARTIES 
Plaintiffs 
5.  Plaintiff IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS is a mission-driven not-for-profit 501(c)(3) 
 
1 GSAs are noncurricular clubs for LGBTQ+ students and their allies to find fellowship and 
community. 
3 
 

Case 4:23-cv-00474-SHL-SBJ   Document 121   Filed 10/23/24   Page 4 of 177
 
organization founded in 2002 and based in Des Moines, Iowa. The mission of IOWA SAFE 
SCHOOLS is to provide safe, supportive, and nurturing learning environments and communities 
for LGBTQ+ and allied youth through education, outreach, advocacy, and direct services. IOWA 
SAFE SCHOOLS pursues this mission by providing services to its members, which include 
individual students and GSAs. IOWA SAFE SCHOOLSโ flagship program is the GSA Network, 
through which IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS provides services and resources to student members and 
member GSAs to empower them in pursuing inclusive school policies, combating anti-LGBTQ+ 
bulling, and supporting one another. IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS provides individualized support to 
its  student  members  and  member  GSAs,  including  through  on-site,  in-person  visits,  direct 
consultation, and connections and coordination with other student groups and IOWA SAFE 
SCHOOLS opportunities. IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS hosts multiple annual student-focused events 
for its members and maintains regular contact with them to provide guidance and address their 
needs at school. IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS assists its student members and member GSAs in their 
advocacy efforts, and additionally advocates on their behalf through coordination with membersโ 
educators and school districts. IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS further performs data collection with 
respect to incidents of anti-LGBTQ+ bullying, harassment, and discrimination, and provides 
services and resources to its members experiencing trauma or tragedy, most notably the loss of a 
friend and fellow member to suicide.  
6.  IOWA  SAFE  SCHOOLS  also  pursues  its  mission  by  providing  professional 
development, licensure renewal, and graduate credits to educators individually and district-wide. 
IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS provides these services through direct consultation programs, in which 
it meets with Iowa educators and school districts to provide guidance on understanding and 
meeting the needs of LGBTQ+ students; an online Iowa Safe Schools Academy that offers 
4 
 

Case 4:23-cv-00474-SHL-SBJ   Document 121   Filed 10/23/24   Page 5 of 177
 
coursework for the fulfillment of license renewal obligations and graduate credits, coursework that 
is primarily focused on supporting different student groups, including LGBTQ+ students; and 
multiple annual conference and symposium opportunities, including the Engage and Empower 
Summit, the Trans Education Summit, and the Anti-Violence Symposium. Through these services, 
IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS works with and provides guidance and programming to educators and 
school  districts  in  developing  and  implementing  school  policies  and  practices  inclusive  of 
LGBTQ+ students and respectful of LGBTQ+ studentsโ rights.  
7.  IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS appears in a dual capacity because as an organization its 
Article III standing can be satisfied in two ways.  
a.  With respect to certain claims2 asserted herein, IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS asserts 
direct organizational standing on its own behalf because SF 496 has perceptibly 
impaired its ability to provide services and referral services to students, both 
individually and through its member GSAs. By chilling the speech and expressive 
association of its member GSAs and students, the law directly interferes with core 
mission and business of IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS. SF 496 has further directly 
interfered with the core mission and business of IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS by 
prohibiting,  discouraging,  and  heightening  the  risk  to  students  and  educators 
pursuing or implementing the inclusive school policies and practices advocated by 
IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS. 
b.  With respect to other claims asserted herein, IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS asserts 
representational standing by appearing on behalf of its members, which includes 
 
2 Individual counts alleged herein specifically identify the capacity in which IOWA SAFE 
SCHOOLS appears in bringing them. 
5 
 

Case 4:23-cv-00474-SHL-SBJ   Document 121   Filed 10/23/24   Page 6 of 177
 
both GSAs as well as individual students who may or may not be currently active 
in a GSA. 
8.  Plaintiff P.B.-P. is a 17-year-old boy who lives in Waterloo in Black Hawk County, 
Iowa. He is a senior at Waterloo West High School. P.B.-P. is the president of Waterloo West High 
Schoolโs GSA, which is a member of IOWA SAFE SCHOOLSโs GSA network. P.B.-P. is 
transgender. He brings this suit by and through his next friend and parent, BELINDA SCARROTT. 
9.  Plaintiff A.C. is a 10-year-old girl who lives in Iowa City, Johnson County, Iowa,

FACTUAL BACKGROUND 
Statutory Background 
35.  SF  496  has  altered  the  landscape  for  Iowa  schools  and  students  through  its 
unconstitutional and discriminatory provisions.  
36.  SF 496, as a whole, in its intent, purpose, and effect, is designed to and is 
accomplishing the silencing and marginalization of students, particularly LGBTQ+ students.  
37.  Plaintiffs highlight three particular provisions of SF 496 that have caused and will 
continue to cause the most damage: those relating to the content of school libraries, those relating 
to the discussion of gender identity or sexual orientation, and those requiring the reporting of 
students expressing a wish for affirmation in their gender identity.   
The Library Restriction  
38.  SF 496 includes multiple provisions that impact and restrict the availability of 
books and other materials in Iowa schools.  
39.  Of particular note is the provision of SF 496 that provides: โEach school district 
shall establish a kindergarten through grade twelve library program that is consistent with section 
280.6 and with the educational standards established in this section, contains only age-appropriate 
materials, and supports the student achievement goals of the total school curriculum.โ SF 496, Div. 
I, ยง 2 (codified at Iowa Code ยง 256.11(9)(a)(2)).  
40.  Prior to SF 496, Iowa Code used the term โage appropriateโ only in reference to 
health class. The term, which has a common understanding of meaning suitable for a particular 
age or age group, was defined separately as โtopics, messages, and teaching methods suitable to 
particular  ages  or  age  groups  of  children  and  adolescents,  based  on  developing  cognitive, 
emotional, and behavioral capacity typical for the age or age group.โ Iowa Code ยง 279.50(10)(a).  
13 
 

Case 4:23-cv-00474-SHL-SBJ   Document 121   Filed 10/23/24   Page 14 of 177
 
41.  Rather than relying upon the ordinary understanding or existing definition in Iowa 
Code, SF 496 created a new definition, which begins by reiterating the above, but then includes an 
express exception: โAge-appropriateโ does not include any material with descriptions or visual 
depictions of a sex act as defined in section 702.17.โ SF 496, Div. I, ยง 4 (codified at Iowa Code ยง 
256.11(19)(a)(1).  
42.  As noted, the term โsex actโ is separately defined in Iowaโs criminal law, alongside 
the term โsexual activityโ; specifically, for purposes of offenses such as lascivious conduct. See 
Iowa Code ยง 702.17. The criminal law defines these terms as โany sexual contact between two or 
more persons by any of the following,โ before listing six examples of qualifying contact between 
two or more personsโ various body parts. See id. 
43.  In short, these provisions of SF 496 obligate Iowa schools to remove any material 
that includes a description or depiction of a sex act. These provisions of SF 496 have been referred 
to as โbook bans.โ Hereinafter, this will be referred to as the โLibrary Restrictionโ of SF 496.  
44.  Most terms within the Library Restriction are undefined.  
45.  The term โlibrary programโ itself has no separate definition within SF 496 or the 
Iowa Code. The term has been reasonably understood in various Iowa school districts as the entire 
offering  of  books  within  the  school  for  student  access,  including  those  within  a  teacherโs 
classroom; a separately designated space within each school for the storage, display, and student 
access of books and other materials; an arrangement with a local community library to provide 
student access during school hours to the books and materials available; or even a โLittle Free 
Libraryโ consisting of a container of books freely donated and removed by students located on or 
near school grounds.   
14 
 

Case 4:23-cv-00474-SHL-SBJ   Document 121   Filed 10/23/24   Page 15 of 177
 
46.  The term โmaterialsโ is not given a definition, either. In context with the word 
โlibrary,โ some school districts have reasonably understood it to include books, periodicals, or 
other examples of a tangible, written word. However, the Library Restriction does not give any 
indication as to its potential application to portable digital media, such as audiobooks or CDs, nor 
as to publications and other informationโor โmaterialsโโavailable on computers provided in 
school libraries for student access.  
47.  Crucially, the Library Restriction fails to define what constitutes a โdescription or 
visual depiction.โ  Whether a word, collection of words, or image โdescribesโ or โdepictsโ 
something is inherently a subjective inquiry; only the reader or viewer of the material receives the 
mental image created by the description or depiction, influenced by their own understanding and 
experiences.  
48.  The Library Restriction does not, for example, provide qualifying or quantifying 
language that would address how specific a description or depiction must be, how frequent such 
descriptions or depictions must occur within a work, or how explicitly they must reveal to the 
recipient of their message that they are referencing the occurrenceโreal or fictionalโof a โsex 
act.โ Whether a description or depiction may be offensive or benign to the reader is immaterial to 
its removal.  
49.  Given  the  creative  medium  of  expression  it  seeks  to  regulate,  the  Library 
Restriction noticeably declines to include any authorization for a school or school employee to 
consider the intended effect of a material, such as whether it appeals to a prurient interest, meaning 
a material containing any description or depiction, even if not intended to evoke sexual excitement 
in the reader, must automatically be removed.  
15 
 

Case 4:23-cv-00474-SHL-SBJ   Document 121   Filed 10/23/24   Page 16 of 177
 
50.  Similarly, the Library Restriction declines to authorize those applying it to consider 
the merit or quality of the material as a whole. Any isolated description or depiction of a sex act 
mandates the materialโs removal from the library program, regardless of whether the work is 
considered a historic or modern-day classic, an essential piece of reading for a college preparatory 
class, or expressing a message of support or inclusion of particular relevance and importance to its 
intended audience.  
51.  Nor does the Library Restriction allow those applying it to consider the grade level 
or levels to which the material is made available. Students in grades 11 and 12 are limited in their 
access to books in the same way as a student in kindergarten.  
52.  The Library Restriction contains a single exception from its scope: compliance with 
Iowa Code ยง 280.6, which states, โReligious books such as the Bible, the Torah, and the Koran 
shall not be excluded from any public school or institution in the state.โ Accordingly, the Library 
Restriction permits such religious books regardless of whether they include a description or 
depiction of a sex act. SF 496, Div. I, ยง 2 (Iowa Code ยง 256.11(9)(a)(1)); see also Iowa Code 
ยง 280.6.    
53.  SF 496 enforces compliance with the Library Restriction mainly through a newly 
created system of investigation and discipline. SF 496 charges the Department of Education with 
investigating library programs in Iowa schools for potential violations of the Library Restriction 
and,  upon  finding  a  violation,  with  issuing  progressively  severe  disciplinary  actionโup  to 
revocation of an educatorโs license and even loss of school accreditation. SF 496, Div. I, ยง 2 
(codified at Iowa Code ยง 256.11(9)(a)(3)(a)โ(b)).   
54.  SF 496 also encourages third party monitoring of schoolsโ and school employeesโ 
compliance with the Library Restriction, by requiring the online publication of all books made 
16 
 

Case 4:23-cv-00474-SHL-SBJ   Document 121   Filed 10/23/24   Page 17 of 177
 
available to students in the school district and authorizing anonymous requests for removal of any 
such book or any other โbook, article, outline, handout, video, or other educational material that is 
available to students.โ SF 496, Div. II, ยง 13 (codified at Iowa Code ยง 279.77(3), (4)). 
55.  Prior to the Library Restriction, the books and materials within Iowa schools were 
selected, in the case of separately identified school library spaces, by qualified teacherโlibrarians 
applying their expertise to select and maintain an appropriate collection of books and materials of 
benefit to the students, and the studentsโ education, in the applicable building. Individual teachers 
also maintained typically smaller collections of books and materials relevant to their studentsโ 
coursework or otherwise suitable for the students accessing their classrooms. These decisions 
were, in either case, subject to the oversight of the local school board, which is authorized to hear 
and decide objections to the inclusion of books and materials.  
56.  Since the Library Restriction was enacted, there has been a statewide culling of 
books and materials available in Iowa schools, whether in designated school libraries or in 
individual teacher classrooms. The number of books removed is estimated to be at least around 
3,400, a figure that is likely underreported as many schools quietly remove books without 
publicizing having done so. Iowa students have thus lost access to untold quantities of information 
that had otherwise been carefully selected for them as suitable for their age and educational 
development.  
The Gender Identity/Sexual Orientation Prohibition 
57.  SF  496  includes  a  sweeping  section  titled,  โSexual  orientation  and  gender 
identityโprohibited instruction,โ that forbids any mention of sexual orientation or gender identity 
from kindergarten through the sixth grade, in or outside of the classroom. Specifically, the law 
prohibits school districts from providing โany program, curriculum, test, survey, questionnaire, 
17 
 

Case 4:23-cv-00474-SHL-SBJ   Document 121   Filed 10/23/24   Page 18 of 177
 
promotion,  or  instruction  relating  to  gender  identity  or  sexual  orientation  to  students  in 
kindergarten through grade six.โ SF 496, Div. II, ยง 16 (Iowa Code ยง 279.80(1)-(2)). This provision 
of SF 496 has been referred to as a โdonโt say gay or transโ law. Hereinafter, this provision of SF 
496  will  be  referred  to  as  the  Gender  Identity/Sexual  Orientation  Prohibition,  or  โGISO 
Prohibition.โ 
58.  Unlike the Library Restriction, the GISO Prohibition does not include an exception 
for human growth and development instruction, i.e., health class. Id. ยง 2 (Iowa Code ยง 256.11(2)-
(3)); SF 496, Div. II, ยง 9 (Iowa Code ยง 279.50(1), (1A)). The seven separate prohibited types of 
speech  under  the  GISO  Prohibitionโany  program,  curriculum,  test,  survey,  questionnaire, 
promotion, or instructionโtaken together would encompass all activities remotely associated with 
a school.  
59.  By using these terms without separate definition, elaboration, or other reference, 
the GISO Prohibition fails to set any limits or bounds on the circumstances to which it applies, 
such that its restrictions conceivably apply to:  
a.  with respect to โprogramโ: in-class and out-of-class activities, coursework, 
school libraries, extracurricular groups, school performances, sports teams, 
bathrooms, after-school events, field trips, or any other offering or activity that 
may conceivably occur on or off school grounds if associated with the school;  
b.  with respect to โcurriculumโ: the courses offered, the assignments or projects 
given, studentsโ self-directed work or the presentation of their work in class, or 
an educatorโs statements or guidance in class;  
c.  with respect to โsurveyโ: formalized surveys such as the Iowa Youth Survey or 
the CDCโs Youth Risk Behavior Survey, or general questions posed to or 
18 
 

Case 4:23-cv-00474-SHL-SBJ   Document 121   Filed 10/23/24   Page 19 of 177
 
assessments taken of a student or group of students (nor whether a โsurveyโ 
holds a separate meaning from โquestionnaireโ or โtestโ);   
d.  with respect to โpromotionโ: displays in school hallways or classrooms, a 
display of books or other materials, in-class reading or discussion, educatorsโ 
self-identification, acknowledgement or affirmance of students, extracurricular 
groups or events, or any other speech, act, or symbol that may be construed as 
โpromotingโ a prohibited concept; and,  
e.  with respect to โinstructionโ: a lecture given to a seated class, discussions with 
students on lessons or their ideas or general wellbeing, discussions between 
students  and  educators  to  form  a  positive  relationship  to  facilitate  class 
participation, or even the permission of a studentโs own speech or expressive 
conduct in or out of class.  
60.  As shown by this non-exhaustive list of potential circumstances to which the GISO 
Prohibition, by its use of seven undefined terms, may apply, the GISO Prohibition makes no 
distinction  based  upon  whether  the  activity  is  mandatory  or  permissive,  curricular  or 
extracurricular. The GISO Prohibitions use of such an expansive list indicates instead that it is 
intended to apply to all.  
61.  Compounding this expansive list of circumstances to which it may apply, the GISO 
Prohibition uses a phrase that must ordinarily be given a very permissive meaning: โrelating to.โ  
62.  Accordingly, the GISO Prohibition is violated if an activity falling within a listed 
circumstance has merely a relation with or nexus to the prohibited concepts, without regard for the 
closeness of that link or the intention of the persons engaging in the activity.  
19 
 

Case 4:23-cv-00474-SHL-SBJ   Document 121   Filed 10/23/24   Page 20 of 177
 
63.  The concepts prohibited by the GISO Prohibition are โgender identityโ and โsexual 
orientation.โ The GISO Prohibition adopts the definition given these terms in the Iowa Civil Rights 
Act; as to โgender identityโ: โa gender-related identity of a person, regardless of the personโs 
assigned sex at birthโ; and, as to โsexual orientationโ: โactual or perceived heterosexuality, 
homosexuality, or bisexuality.โ  The GISO Prohibition does not, on its face, distinguish between 
LGBTQ+ identities and orientations, and cisgender identities and heterosexual orientations. This 
textual failing creates inconsistencies with other Iowa statutes recently passed by the legislature, 
including a requirement that sports teams be designated by gender and prohibits participation in 
girls teams based on the studentโs sex assigned at birth (see Iowa Code ยง 261I.2(1)(a)โ(b)); as well 
as a โbathroom billโ that prohibits access to restrooms, changing areas, overnight accommodations, 
and other spaces based upon the studentโs sex assigned at birth (see Iowa Code ยง 280.33(1)โ(2)).  
64.  Notwithstanding these otherwise neutral definitions of gender identity and sexual 
orientation, State Defendants have taken the position in this litigation that an interpretation of the 
GISO Prohibition that would include within its scope cisgender identities and heterosexual 
orientations would be absurd. State Defendants have articulated an interpretation of the GISO 
Prohibition that applies only to LGBTQ+ identities and orientations, and subjects only the concepts 
of non-cisgender identity and non-heterosexual orientation to prohibition. For example, in giving 
an example of โmandatoryโ instruction that would violate the GISO Prohibition, State Defendants 
noted an in-class reading of a book featuring gay or transgender characters.  
65.  The GISO Prohibition also includes complications in application and enforcement 
due to the grade levels chosen. Iowa schools do not uniformly, if even generally, designate 
buildings solely for use by kindergarten through sixth grade; rather, it is common for sixth graders 
to attend either middle schools or junior highs along with students in grades seven or eight, thus

subjecting those students otherwise falling outside its restrictions to restraints on their activity to 
ensure compliance as to the sixth graders in their presence.    
66.  Unlike  the  Library  Restriction,  the  GISO  Prohibition  includes  no  separately 
described enforcement mechanism. Instead, SF 496 makes its obligations a condition of a school 
districtโs accreditation. SF 496, Div. I, ยง 2 (codified at Iowa Code ยง 256.11(2)(3)).   
67.  Prior to the GISO Prohibition, many Iowa schools engaged in proactive efforts to 
support the inclusion, affirmation, and safety of students who were LGBTQ+ themselves or came 
from families with LGBTQ+ members. Among these efforts were the display of symbols or 
messages of support for the LGBTQ+ community, sponsoring and facilitating LGBTQ+ student 
groups, providing students with factual information on transgender and nonbinary gender identities 
in  response  to  or  to  protect  against  anti-transgender  bullying  and  harassment,  ensuring  the 
availability of books and materials that included LGBTQ+ representation alongside traditionally 
represented straight and cisgender characters, checking in with students to ensure they felt included 
and represented in class, and allowing student speech and conduct, including the preparation and 
presentation of classroom projects or assignments, on issues relating to LGBTQ+ identities, 
orientations, and rights.  
68.  Since the GISO Prohibition, these Iowa schools have eliminated or rolled back all 
such efforts and have instead taken steps to ensure issues relating to LGBTQ+ identities and 
orientations are not acknowledged or addressed in the school or school-related environments. In 
addition to direct prohibitions on student speech, conduct, and association, this curtailment of 
LGBTQ+ inclusion and its consequent message of LGBTQ+ exclusion has chilled students and 
forced them to self-censor on topics related to their or their friendsโ and family membersโ LGBTQ+ 
identity or orientation. In addition to the negative consequences this restriction on expression and

deprivation  of  information  has  had  on  these  studentsโ  educational  outcomes  and  emotional 
wellbeing, it has further put LGBTQ+ students at increased risk of anti-LGBTQ+ bullying and 
harassment.  
The Gender Identity Notification Provision 
69.  Finally, SF 496 includes a Gender Identity Notification Provision, which has been 
referred to as a โforced outingโ provision. The Gender Identity Notification Provision forces 
school officials to notify a studentโs parent or guardian whenever a student asks school officials to 
respect the studentโs gender identity, even when the school has reason to believe that doing so will 
result in imminent harm, homelessness, or abuse of the student at the hands of their parents or 
guardians. SF 496, Div. II, ยง 14 (Iowa Code ยง 279.78(3)).  
70.  Specifically, the Gender Identity Notification Provision states: โIf a student . . . 
requests an accommodation that is intended to affirm the studentโs gender identity from a licensed 
practitioner employed by the school district,โ the licensed practitioner must โreport the studentโs 
request to an administrator,โ who then โshall report the studentโs request to the studentโs parent or 
guardian.โ Id.  
71.  The Gender Identity Notification Provision includes only one example of what 
might qualify as a requested โaccommodation,โ noting that this term is โincluding a request that 
the licensed practitioner address the student using a name or pronoun that is different than the 
name or pronoun assigned to the student in the school districtโs registration forms or records.โ Id. 
As  the  example  of  a  request  for  gender-affirming  names  or  pronouns  is  only  one  of  the 
circumstances โinclud[ed]โ within its scope, the Gender Identity Notification Provision leaves 
significant room for other reportable requests.  
22

72.  The Gender Identity Notification Provision does not include limiting language that 
would exempt from its reporting obligation common expressions of a transgender or gender 
nonconforming studentโs gender identity, such as organizing a GSA and participating openly in its 
meetings and events, and thus actions can necessitate a report home.  
73.  As a GSAโs mission is to support free expression of LGBTQ+ identity and inclusion 
of LGBTQ+ persons by providing students with a safe environment to freely express themselves, 
find support and community, access resources, and advocate for appropriate changes to school 
policy, the Gender Identity Notification Provision thus necessarily impacts GSAsโ operations in 
ways inapplicable to other student-led, noncurricular groups, in addition to its impact on the 
students themselves.  
74.  Furthermore, the Gender Identity Notification Provision contains no exception for 
incidents  of  anti-LGBTQ  bullying  or  harassment.  Under  the  Gender  Identity  Notification 
Provision, a student who reports being bullied or harassed because of their transgender or gender 
nonconforming status must also expect they will be outed to their parents or guardians.  
75.  Similarly, the Gender Identity Notification Provision contains no exception for 
disclosures made while the student is receiving school-provided mental health counseling or social 
services, regardless of the studentโs expectation of confidentiality or, indeed, the psychologistโs, 
counselorโs, social workerโs, or nurseโs own ethical obligations. A student who privately reveals 
their gender identity to a trusted professional may be blindsided when that professional breaks 
confidentiality to initiate a mandated report to the studentโs parents or guardians.  
76.  The  Gender Identity Notification Provision requires that school districts, including 
Defendant School Districts, their administrators, and their employees, make this notification to 
parents and guardians regardless of the studentโs wishes or plans for sharing this information with 
23

their parents or guardians; regardless of whether a student will be rendered unsafe as a result; 
regardless of whether a student may have a reasonable expectation of confidentiality when 
speaking with a school psychologist, counselor, social worker, or nurse; and regardless of ethical 
obligations these professionals may have to protect confidentiality. The law contains no process 
for determining whether the studentโs safety or wellbeing will be threatened as result of such a 
disclosure. It also does not contain any exception allowing for a school employee to avoid parental

77.  The enforcement mechanism for the Gender Identity Notification Provision is 
similar to the Library Restriction, in that an investigation and disciplinary procedure specific to 
this provision has been added by SF 496. In short, the Department of Education is required to 
enforce this mandate by investigating potential violations and imposing disciplinary action ranging 
from written warnings to proceedings that could result in loss of licensure or certification.  (Iowa 
Code ยง 279.78(4)). As is the case with any violation of state law, upon disciplinary action, 
superintendents and school boards have the ability to terminate a teacher. See Iowa Code ยง 
279.27(1)โ(2). 
78.  Prior to the Gender Identity Notification Provision, Iowa educators, based on their 
training,  experience,  and  the  positive  impact  apparent,  would  endeavor  to  form  trusting 
relationships with their students. With this trust in place, Iowa educators had greater insight into a 
studentโs  emotional  wellbeing,  including  their  home  situation,  and  consequently  a  greater 
opportunity to address the challenges a student was facing in their academic performance. This 
relationship further allowed educators to  fulfill their obligations as mandatory  reporters, as 
students felt comfortable seeking out these trusted adults for help with abuse at the hands of their

parents or guardians. Separately, Iowa educators facilitated LGBTQ+ student groups and allowed 
open discussion on issues relating to gender identity within them, to create a safe space for students 
to engage with each other and form support structures in the school environment. Facilitating such 
groups  further  allowed  Iowa  educators  to  head  off  unsafe  or  inappropriate  behavior,  and 
additionally provided the opportunity to encourage and provide guidance to transgender or gender 
nonconforming students in disclosing their gender identity at home.  
79.  Since  the  Gender  Identity  Notification  Provision,  Iowa  educators  have  been 
reluctant to form these bonds with students, given the risk that a student from a non-affirming 
home environment could feel safeโand then betrayedโin revealing their gender identity to a 
trusted educator. Students similarly have been reluctant to ask questions or share their struggles 
with gender identity, effectively placing a wall between them and those with the obligation to 
report them. Meanwhile, students from homes that are affirming of their gender identity have 
refrained from engaging with or encouraging teacher engagement with fellow students believed to 
be struggling with their gender identity in a non-affirming home environment, not wanting to put 
either the student at risk of abuse at home or the educator at risk of discipline in failing to make a 
required report. The Gender Identity Notification Requirement has thus forced students to engage 
in self-censorship, exposed them to domestic violence and homelessness, prevented them from 
forming or continuing a trusted a relationship with an adult teacher or advisor, increased the 
likelihood of isolation and ostracization by peers, and undermined any expectation that they may 
have had that their school environment would be a safe space for learning where teachers could 
help protect them from bullying or abuse.

80.  On November 15, 2023, Defendant ISBE issued proposed rules implementing SF 
496, including new enforcement mechanisms the law requires. Although the rulemaking purports 
to clarify aspects of SF 496, the proposed rules raise new questions and do not address the 
vagueness of the statutory language in any meaningful way.  
81.  For example, the proposed rules purport to limit the definition of โage-appropriate,โ 
which the statute defines as excluding โany material with descriptions or visual depictions of a sex 
act,โ by adding, โA reference or mention of a sex act in a way that does not describe or visually 
depict a sex act as defined in that section is not included in the previous sentence.โ Iowa State 
Board of Education, Notice of Intended Action, Item 2 (amending Iowa Admin. Code r. 281-12.2) 
(hereinafter, โProposed Rulesโ).  
82.  This proposed rule does not clarify when a โreferenceโ or โmention of a sex actโ 
does or does not qualify as โdescrib[ing]โ a โsex act.โ  
83.  This proposed rule also does not explain whether enforcement turns on the brevity 
of the description, whether the description is merely implicit, the degree to which the description 
plays a role in a broader narrative, whether the average person would find the reference to appeal 
to the prurient interest, or take into account the literary, artistic, political, or scientific value of the 
work. 
84.   The  proposed  rules  modify  the  enforcement  provisions  of  SF  496โs  Library 
Restriction by specifying that Defendant IDOE โmay exercise enforcement discretion if any 
violation is voluntarily and permanently corrected prior to the department making a determination 
of a violation.โ Proposed Rules, Item 4 (amending Iowa Admin. Code r. 281-12.3(12)(d)(3)).

Legislative History of SF 496 
104.  The landscape of Iowa law before the passage of SF 496, along with the lawโs 
legislative history, underscore that SF 496 was not enacted for any legitimate purpose and

105.  Prior  to  SF  496,  Iowa  law  contained  numerous  protections  for  students  that 
protected them from exposure to harmful materials in school.  
106.  Iowa law prohibited the dissemination of obscene material to minors and the 
admission of minors to premises where obscene material is exhibited. See Iowa Code ยง 728.2, 
728.3.  
107.  Iowa law also provided for the creation and oversight of appropriate, supportive 
school library programs. See 281 Iowa Admin. Code r. 12.3(12)(a)โ(c).  
108.  And Iowa law required each school district to adopt policies to address the selection 
and reconsideration of school libraries. See 281 Iowa Admin. Code r. 12.3(12)(c).

SF 496 has Caused Direct Harm to Plaintiff Iowa Safe Schools 
and its Student and GSA Members 
131.  IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS serves a network of chapter member GSAs, which are 
student-led organizations and noncurricular clubs within schools that focus on providing a safe 
space  for  LGBTQ+  youth,  address  anti-LGBTQ+  harassment  and  discrimination,  promote 
inclusion, offer support to students, and educate people about sexual orientation and gender 
identity.  
132.  IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS serves its member GSAs in multiple ways, providing 
guidance to members forming new GSAs and supporting their goals throughout the school year, 
including individualized support in on-site visits, workshops, connections to other network GSAs 
and access to several annual events, and written resources on issues relevant to operating a GSA 
and supporting and advocating for LGBTQ+ youth.  
133.  IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS also serves individual student members and groups of 
students who are not yet members of a GSA, including by providing resources and consultation 
on forming GSAs, materials and victim service information regarding bullying, and all other 
benefits of the GSA Network, such as access to events and scholarship opportunities. These 
students are part of the IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS GSA network regardless of whether they are 
members of an active GSA. In other words, numerous GSAs and individual LGBTQ+ students 
throughout Iowa are members of IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS.

CLAIMS FOR RELIEF  
I.  VIOLATION OF THE FIRST AMENDMENT FOR OVERBREADTH 
199.  The Library Restriction and Gender Identity/Sexual Orientation Prohibition, on 
their face, violate the First Amendment as overbroad.   
200.  The First Amendment, as applied to the states through the Fourteenth Amendment 
and enforceable pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983, provides in part that the government โshall make 
no law . . . abridging the freedom of speech . . . of the right of the people peaceably to assemble.โ  
201.  Under the First Amendment, a law may be invalidated as overbroad if a substantial 
number of its applications are unconstitutional, judged in relation to the statuteโs plainly legitimate 
60 
 

Case 4:23-cv-00474-SHL-SBJ   Document 121   Filed 10/23/24   Page 61 of 177
 
sweep. This less demanding standard for facial challenges in First Amendment cases exists to 
provide breathing room for free expression.  
202.  The first step in a facial analysis is to assess the scope of the challenged laws; 
expressed differently, to ask: what activities, by what actors, do the laws prohibit or otherwise 
regulate?  As described in greater detail in the counts below, these challenged provisions of SF 
496 are of a staggering, unprecedentedly broad scope.   
203.  The second step in a facial analysis is to determine which of the lawsโ applications 
violate the First Amendment.  As described in greater detail in the counts below, and as further 
articulated in other claims asserted on First Amendment grounds in this Complaint, a substantial 
number of the provisionsโ applications violate the First Amendment.   
204.  The third step in a facial analysis is to measure the unconstitutional applications 
against  the  remaining  provisions.  As  described  in  greater  detail  in  the  counts  below,  the 
applications of the provisions that remain are insignificant when compared to the unconstitutional 
applications.     
Count 1  
The Library Restriction is Facially Unconstitutional for Overbreadth

Representational Capacity on behalf of its Individual Student Members, against All Defendants. 
a.  Plaintiff IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS, in its representational capacity on behalf of its 
student members, states this claim against State Defendants, and against School 
District Defendants. 
b.  Plaintiff  P.B.-P.  states  this  claim  against  State  Defendants  and  Waterloo 
Community School District Defendants.

c.  Plaintiff A.C. states this claim against State Defendants and Iowa City Community

d.  Plaintiffs T.S. and B.F. state this claim against State Defendants and Urbandale

e.  Plaintiff B.F.S. states this claim against State Defendants and West Des Moines

206.  Plaintiffs incorporate paragraphs 199 through 204 as if fully set forth herein.  
207.  The Library Restriction includes within its scope the operation of all kindergarten 
through grade twelve library programs in the State of Iowaโs public school system.  
208.  The term โlibrary programโ is undefined but generally understood to mean the 
space each Iowa elementary school, middle school, junior high, or high school sets aside in the 
building or by arrangement with a local public library for the collection of books and other 
materials and resources made available to the students attending such schools. 
209.  The term โlibrary programโ may also include within its scope the collections of 
books commonly maintained in individual teachersโ classrooms. 
210.  The Library Restriction imposes a new restriction on the โmaterial,โ principally 
books, though often including other media such as audiobooks, movies, music, or games, which 
may be made available to the students who access such library spaces. 
211.  Thus,  the  Library  Restriction  regulates  actors  including  the  schools,  school 
employees, and, in the case of local libraries made available to the school by agreement, third 
parties maintaining these libraries, as well as the students who are accessing them.   
62 
 

Case 4:23-cv-00474-SHL-SBJ   Document 121   Filed 10/23/24   Page 63 of 177
 
212.  The activities from which these actors are restricted is the inclusion of or, in the 
case of students, access to, any material that includes a โdescription[] or visual depiction[] of a sex 
act.โ The term โsex actโ is separately defined in Iowa Code to mean sexual contact, in its various 
forms, between two or more persons.  
213.  This definitional term does not include any qualification or adjustment for the 
frequency, type, or character of the descriptions or depictions contained within the material, the 
materialโs target audience or its restricted availability within the school system to students of 
certain grades, the materialโs intention as to the inclusion of such a description or depiction, the 
materialโs merit or value in other respects when taken as a whole, or any other characteristic of the 
material or its audience, with the exception of โthe Bible, the Torah, . . . the Koran,โ and undefined 
other โreligious books,โ which are excluded from the Library Restriction notwithstanding any 
descriptions or depictions of a sex act contained therein.  
214.  Accordingly, the Library Restriction includes within its scope a massive amount of 
books and materials that had previously been made available in Iowa school libraries by and, in 
the case of students, accessed by, these actors because of the booksโ and materialsโ quality and 
identified support for the schoolsโ and studentsโ educational goals.  
215.  An application of the Library Restriction violates the First Amendment if it results 
in a removal of books or materials that unjustifiably infringes upon a studentโs right to receive 
information.

II. VIOLATION OF THE FIRST AND FOURTEENTH AMENDMENTS FOR 
VAGUENESS  
259.  The  Library  Restriction,  Gender  Identity/Sexual  Orientation  Prohibition,  and 
Gender Identity Notification Provision are, on their face, unconstitutionally vague in violation the 
First and Fourteenth Amendments.  
260.  The Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment, enforceable pursuant to 42 
U.S.C. ยง 1983, provides that โ[n]o state shall . . . deprive any person of life, liberty, or property, 
without due process of law.โ  
261.  A law is unconstitutionally vague in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment if it 
fails to provide adequate notice of the proscribed conduct and authorizes or encourages arbitrary 
enforcement.  
262.  A severe enforcement mechanism lessens the degree of tolerable vagueness.  
73 
 

Case 4:23-cv-00474-SHL-SBJ   Document 121   Filed 10/23/24   Page 74 of 177
 
263.  To the extent a law intrudes upon an area protected by the First Amendment, 
standards of permissible vagueness are strict, and the government may regulate only the matter 
only with narrow specificity.

281.  The Gender Identity/Sexual Orientation Prohibition fails to provide people of 
ordinary  intelligence  a  reasonable  opportunity  to  understand  what  conduct  it  prohibits  and 
authorizes or encourages arbitrary and discriminatory enforcement.  
282.  The GISO Prohibition is vague as to the activities to which it applies: โany program, 
curriculum, test, survey, questionnaire, promotion, or instruction.โ By use of the term โany,โ the 
GISO Prohibition indicates that the listed terms are intended to be interpreted as broadly as 
possible.  
283.  The ordinary understanding of a program is โa public notice,โ a โperformanceโ or 
โoutline of the order to be followed, of the features to be presented, and the persons participatingโ 
in a performance; โa plan or system under which action may be taken toward a goal,โ โcurriculum,โ 
or โprospectus, syllabus.โ Separately, an โEducational Programโ is defined under Iowa law as โthe 
entire offering of the school, including out-of-class activities and the sequences of curriculum areas 
and activities,โ and the phrase โlibrary programโ is used elsewhere in SF 496, namely, in the 
Library Restriction.  
284.  The GISO Prohibition fails to identify to which of these uses of the term program, 
as ordinarily understood or separately defined in Iowa law, it refers, such that a person of ordinary 
intelligence is not given a reasonable opportunity to understand if its regulations apply to the 
entirety of in-class and out-of-class activities, coursework, school libraries, extracurricular groups, 
school performances, sport teams, bathrooms, after-school events, field trips, or any other offering 
or activity that may conceivably occur on or off school grounds if associated with the school.

and gender-fair approach to education, such that a person of ordinary intelligence is not given a

286.  The ordinary understanding of survey is, as to appraisals, โto examine as to 
condition, situation, or value,โ โto query (someone) in order to collect data for the analysis of some 
aspect of a group or areaโ; as to land, to take measurements; and otherwise, โto view or consider

Further, the term survey is used by State Defendants to refer to the Iowa Youth Survey, and is also

287.  The term โquestionnaireโ does not appear elsewhere in SF 496. It is generally

III. VIOLATION OF THE FIRST AMENDMENT RIGHTS  
TO FREEDOM OF SPEECH AND EXPRESSION   
335.  The  Library  Restriction,  Gender  Identity/Sexual  Orientation  Prohibition,  and 
Gender Identity Notification Provision, on their face, violate the First Amendment rights to receive 
information and engage in speech, expressive conduct, and expressive association.  
336.  The First Amendment, as applied to the states through the Fourteenth Amendment 
and enforceable pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983, provides in part that the government โshall make 
no law . . . abridging the freedom of speech . . . of the right of the people peaceably to assemble.โ  
337.  In the case of private, noncurricular speech or expressive conduct in the school 
setting, the right to engage in such speech and expressive conduct is unconstitutionally infringed 
upon when restricted despite not presenting a material and substantial interference with the 
requirements of appropriate discipline in the operation of school or impinging upon the rights of 
other students.  
338.  Government regulation of private speech based on viewpoint discrimination is 
subject to strict scrutiny, requiring the government to demonstrate the restriction is narrowly 
tailored and necessary to further a compelling governmental interest.  
339.  Government laws and actions violate the First Amendment when, taken as a whole, 
they create a chilling effect that deters free speech and association rights because they target such 
expression. 
91 
 

Case 4:23-cv-00474-SHL-SBJ   Document 121   Filed 10/23/24   Page 92 of 177
 
340.  In the case of speech or expressive conduct considered school-sponsored, the right 
to engage in such speech and expressive conduct is unconstitutionally infringed upon if the speech 
or expressive conduct is restricted without reasonable relation to a legitimate pedagogical concern. 
341.  In the school setting, the right to receive information is unconstitutionally infringed 
upon when information otherwise made available in the school is removed from studentsโ access 
without adequate governmental justification.

347.  On its face, as legislative history shows, and based on State Defendantsโ own

V. VIOLATION OF EQUAL PROTECTION UNDER THE FOURTEENTH 
AMENDMENT 
564.  SF 496, on its face and as applied, as a whole and with respect to the Gender 
Identity/Sexual Orientation Prohibition and Gender Identity Notification Provision, violates the 
Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.  
565.  The Fourteenth Amendment, enforceable pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983, provides 
that โ[n]o state shall . . . deny to any person within its jurisdiction the equal protection of the laws.โ 
566.  When determining whether a classification based on sex, sexual orientation, gender 
identity,  or  transgender  status  violates  the  Equal  Protection  Clause,  courts  must  view  that 
classification with heightened scrutiny, as these traits โgenerally provide no sensible ground for 
differential treatment.โ  
567.  As a result, the state must provide an โexceedingly persuasive justificationโ for 
laws that differentiate on the basis of sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, or transgender status. 
If the state cannot provide such a justification, the law is unconstitutional.

Prohibition, this portion of the law has been widely interpreted as restricting only discussion of 
non-heterosexual orientations and non-cisgender identities. As such, the GISO Prohibition, as 
applied, targets only LGBTQ+ students in schools on the basis of their gender identity or sexual 
orientation, and therefore violates the Equal Protection Clause. 
589.  Moreover, by failing to provide clear boundaries on the speech prohibited under the 
GISO Prohibition, SF 496 invites and has resulted in arbitrary and discriminatory enforcement.   
590.  For example, some schools have disallowed GSAs from meeting or declined to 
provide GSAs resources in schools with students in kindergarten through sixth grade, who are 
expressly subject to the GISO Prohibition. Others have prohibited GSAs with older students from 
hanging posters or otherwise promoting their meetings in areas of schools where K-6 students may 
be present.  In addition, some GSA leaders have been told they cannot invite 5th or 6th grade 
students to their meetings. 
591.  The GISO Prohibition therefore subjects these students to differential and adverse 
treatment on the basis of their sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, or transgender status. 
592.  State Defendants, who are responsible for the adoption and implementation of the 
GISO  Prohibition,  do  not,  and  cannot,  offer  any  legitimate  governmental  purpose  for  the 
provisionโs differential and adverse treatment of these students on the basis of their sex, sexual 
orientation, gender identity, or transgender status. 
593.  SF 496โs GISO Prohibition serves no legitimate governmental purpose, let alone 
an exceedingly persuasive or compelling one.

604.  SF 496โs Gender Identity Notification Provision has resulted in the differential and 
adverse treatment of Plaintiff Students and Iowa Safe Schools, as an organization and in its 
representational capacity on behalf of its GSAs and Individual Student Members on the basis of 
their sex, gender identity, and transgender status, thus violating their Equal Protection rights under

605.  SF 496โs Gender Identity Notification Provision expressly targets students who

provision makes no such requirement for non-LGBTQ+ students whose names and pronouns align 
with those in their school records.

differential and adverse treatment on the basis of their sex, gender identity, and transgender status.

VI.  VIOLATION OF THE EQUAL ACCESS ACT OF 1984  
619.  SF 496, as applied, violates the Equal Access Act of 1984, 20 U.S.C. ยง 4071.  
620.  The Equal Access Act ensures that noncurricular student groups are afforded the 
same access to public secondary school facilities as other, similarly situated student groups.   
152 
 

Case 4:23-cv-00474-SHL-SBJ   Document 121   Filed 10/23/24   Page 153 of 177
 
621.  The Act applies to any public secondary school that receives federal funds and 
creates a limited open forum by allowing one or more noncurricular student groups to meet on its 
premises during non-instructional time. Schools meeting these criteria are forbidden to prevent 
access or deny fair opportunity to students who wish to hold meetings on school grounds. 
622.  Schools allowing at least one noncurricular related student group may not deny 
comparable access to any other student group because of the religious, political, philosophical, or 
other content of the speech at the groupโs meetings. The Act therefore prohibits schools from 
banning student-led noncurricular groups because of the content of the speech at the groupsโ 
meetings. 
623.  โAccessโ and โfair opportunityโ refer not only to physical meeting spaces on school 
premises, but also to recognition and privileges afforded to other groups at the school, including, 
for example, the right to announce club meetings in the school newspaper, on bulletin boards, or 
over the public-address system. 
624.  The Act does not permit schools to ban a group based on school officialsโ general 
moral disapproval or on assumptions about the content of speech at group meetings. A school 
violates the Act by excluding, preventing access, or denying a fair opportunity to a group based on 
the fact that the group addresses issues of interest to LGBTQ+ students. The Act requires the 
school to treat each group like other groups and prohibits imposing additional requirements on 
some student-run groups that are not imposed on all others.

documents.title: Renewed Motion for Preliminary Injunction
documents.text:
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT  
FOR THE SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF IOWA  
CENTRAL DIVISION 
 
 
IOWA SAFE SCHOOLS f/k/a GLBT YOUTH IN  Case No.   4:23-cv-474   
IOWA SCHOOLS TASK FORCE, et al.,   
   
    Plaintiffs,   RENEWED MOTION FOR 
  PRELIMINARY INJUNCTION 
  v. 
 
KIM REYNOLDS, in her official capacity as 
Governor of the State of Iowa et al.,  
 
    Defendants.  
 
 
  Plaintiffs hereby move for a preliminary injunction pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil 
Procedure 65 to prevent further irreparable injury pending final adjudication of Plaintiffsโ action. 
This Motion is submitted upon Plaintiffsโ First Amended Complaint and is supported by 
the accompanying Brief in Support of Plaintiffsโ Renewed Motion for Preliminary Injunction of 
SF 496, the sworn Declarations of Becky Tayler, Executive Director of Plaintiff Iowa Safe Schools 
(โISSโ); Hannah Mitchell, Director of Youth Engagement of Plaintiff ISS; Jordan Mix, Director 
of Educational Programming for Plaintiff ISS; Plaintiff P.B.-P.; Plaintiff A.C., Parent and Next 
Friend Richard Carlson; Parent and Next Friend Ulrike Carlson; Plaintiff T.S.; Plaintiff B.F.S.; 
Parent and Next Friend Brigit Stevens; Plaintiff B.F.; Plaintiff James Doe; Plaintiff Daniel 
Gutmann; Plaintiff Alyson Telford; non-party Declarant F.J.; non-party Declarant Cindy Harper; 
non-party Declarant Elesha Gayman Shahinllari and any other material the Court may consider at 
any hearing on this Motion. These Declarations include additional evidence of irreparable harm 
that has occurred to student members of ISS and chapter GSA members since the law took effect, 
including in the months after the Courtโs grant of a partial preliminary injunction as to the other 
1 
 

provisions of SF 496 on December 29, 2023, and the Eighth Circuit Courtโs opinion reversing this 
Courtโs order, vacating the partial injunction, and remanding the case back to this Court for 
reconsideration of Plaintiffsโ as-applied challenges, and facial challenges in light of Moody v. 
NetChoice, LLC, 144 S. Ct. 2383 (2024). 
As  Plaintiffs  set  forth  in  their  accompanying  Brief  in  Support  of  Plaintiffsโ 
Renewed Motion for Preliminary Injunction, Plaintiffs are likely to succeed on the merits of their 
claims. Senate File 496, 2023 Iowa Acts ch. 91 (โSF 496โ or โthe lawโ), violates the First and 
Fourteenth Amendments through its three principle provisions: the โLibrary Restriction,โ โGender 
Identity/Sexual Orientation Prohibitionโ (or, โGISO Prohibitionโ),  and  the โGender  Identity 
Notification Provision.โ Plaintiffs move for preliminary injunction on their claims the Library 
Restriction is overbroad, vague, and infringes upon their First Amendment right to receive 
information; the GISO Prohibition is overbroad, vague, and infringes upon their First Amendment 
rights to engage in speech, expressive conduct, and expressive association; and the Gender Identity 
Notification Provision is vague and infringes upon their First Amendment right to engage in 
expressive association. To obtain a preliminary injunction, Plaintiffs โneed only establish a 
likelihood of succeeding on the merits of any one of [their] claims.โ Richland/Wilkin Joint Powers 
Auth. v. U.S. Army Corps of Engโrs, 826 F.3d 1030, 1040 (8th Cir. 2016) (quoting Am. Rivers v. 
U.S. Army Corps of Engโrs, 271 F. Supp. 2d 230, 250 (D.D.C. 2003)).  
As Plaintiffs establish in the accompanying Brief in Support of Plaintiffsโ Renewed Motion 
for Preliminary Injunction, Plaintiffs are suffering and will continue to suffer irreparable injury 
absent an injunction. The balance of equities also is in Plaintiffsโ favor, and it is โalways in the 
public interest to prevent the violation of a partyโs constitutional rights.โ D.M. by Bao Xiong v. 
Minn. State High Sch. League, 917 F.3d 994, 1004 (8th Cir. 2019) (quoting Awad v. Ziriax, 670 
2 
 

F.3d 1111, 1132 (10th Cir. 2012)). Plaintiffs request that the Court waive the requirement of bond 
in Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 65(c). Richland/Wilkin, 826 F.3d at 1043 (whether to require 
bond is within courtโs discretion). Public interest litigation is a recognized exception to the bond 
requirement, especially where, as here, requiring a bond would injure the constitutional rights of 
Plaintiffs and the relief sought would not pose a hardship to government Defendants. See id.  
Dated: October 18, 2024        Respectfully submitted, 
/s/  
Thomas D. Story, AT0013130 (Lead Counsel)  Camilla B. Taylor* 
Rita Bettis Austen, AT0011558  Nathan Maxwell* **  
Shefali Aurora, AT0012874  Kenneth D. Upton, Jr.* ***

Case 4:23-cv-00474-SHL-SBJ     Document 141     Filed 05/15/25     Page 2 of 35
JANELLE  EWING,  and  KRYSTAL  MADLOCK,  in

in his official capacity as West Des Moines Community

MONTOYA  STARR,  FANNETTE  ELLIOTT,  JILL
